titleStmt.title: Dolbenmaen 2

editor.orgName: Maynooth University, Department of Early Irish

titleStmt.funder: Irish Research Council (grant no. IRC/W001985/1) and Arts and Humanities Research Council (grant no. AH/W001985/1)

funder.ref: UK-Ireland Collaboration in the Digital Humanities Research Grant

msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in Ogham script
Latin written in Latin script with a Celtic personal name

support.p: Gwynedd Archaeological Trust Regional Historic Environment Record: 136 Llystyn-gwyn Farm
support.note: dolerite microgabbro with a typical thick weathering crust and a homogenous texture (Edwards 2013, 270)

supportDesc.condition: The stone is partially obscured by vegetation and rubbish. There is minor damage to the surface of the stone. The ogham and roman-letter inscriptions are very weathered (Edwards 2013, 270).

layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with an ogham inscription on the right edge of the stone beginning about halfway to the top of the stone continuing over the top, reading vertically upwards. The placement of the ogham inscription on the right angle is more unusual but is paralleled in the north on Llanfaelog (W-AGY-001). The stone is also inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in three lines at the top of the face, justified to the right, reading horizontally. Edwards (2013, 272) notes that the combination of a horizontal roman-letter inscription with ogham is unusual but is paralleled on Clocaenog 1 (D1), Castell Dwyran 1 (CM3) and Nevern 2 (P71). According to Edwards (2013, 272), the positioning of the roman-letter inscription towards the right angle of the stone where the ogham is located is surely intentional and signals a relationship between the two inscriptions.

handDesc.handNote: Macalister (1945, 361) described the ogham inscription as pocked and rubbed and Edwards (2013, 271) described the inscription as incised using broad lines and a punch. The Roman-letter inscription is set out unevenly in capitals with miniscule S. The R has an open loop and the diagonal is seperate; the diagonals of V in the first line do not meet and touch the horizontal bar of the T in the second line; the tail of the S likewise touches the top of the I below; the diagonal of the N in the second line veers slightly towards the horizontal (Edwards 2013, 270-1).

origin.origPlace: Dolbenmaen, Caithness, Wales 52.983411, -4.261431 National Grid Reference: SH 4828 4529
origin.origDate: Late fifth or earlier sixth century A.D.

history.provenance: Locally derived stone, first found in 1901 when it was removed to avoid obstructing a gateway approximately 300m north-north-east of Pen Llystyn Roman fort. The ogham inscription was discovered in 1903 when the stone was moved and set the right way up.
Set into the stone wall on the south side of the farmyard west of the farmhouse (SH 4821 4553).

graphic.desc: Drawing of Dolbenmaen stone. © Crown copyright: RCAHMW

app.note: Edwards (2013, 272) remarked that although the details of the ogham inscription are difficult to see due to the location of the stone, the inscription has been consistently read as ICORIGAS.

div.p: The name Icorix has no known descendants in later Welsh or Irish. In theory, Old Irish Echrí could continue *Icorix, but it is more likely to be from *Ekworix 'horse-king' (Edwards 2013, 273). If the name is British, the ogham presumably uses C rather than G either following the roman lettering or following the Irish cognate (Edwards 2013, 272-3).

The Roman-letter inscription is in the 'X son of Y' formula. The first name in the inscription,Icorix appears to have both British and Celtic influence while Potentinus is Latin and use of this is paralleled elsewhere in Britain and Ireland (Edwards 2013, 272-3). On the context of the stone, Edwards' notes the presence of a Roman auxiliary fort at Pen Llystyn and argues that the stone relates to continuing activity in the area of the fort, which would have remained a prominent landmark, in the post-Roman period (Edwards 2013, 271-2).
